case_vignette: A 37-year-old male with a history of HIV presents to the emergency room with back pain. He reports intermittent fevers for the past week. He reports that he chose to come to the emergency room now because the back pain is more severe and he has also started having trouble controlling his bowels. His vital signs are Temp 38.5 C, HR 100, BP 110/70, RR 16, and O2 99% on room air. Exam of his arm is shown in Figure A. On physical examination of his back and extremities, there is tenderness to palpation along the lower spine, weakness in the bilateral legs (right greater than left), and hyporeflexia bilaterally. Rectal examination reveals saddle anesthesia.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having back pain, intermittent fevers for the past week, and recently I'm having trouble controlling my bowels.
Have you had any recent injuries, surgeries, or infections?
No, I haven't had any recent injuries, surgeries, or infections.
Do you have any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your legs or feet?
Yes, I have weakness in both of my legs, and it's worse on the right side.
Have you experienced any changes in bladder function, such as retention or incontinence?
Yes, I've started having trouble controlling my bowels.
Do you have a history of cancer, immunosuppression, or use of medications such as steroids or biologics?
I have a history of HIV.
Is the back pain you're experiencing localized in one area, or does it spread anywhere?
The back pain is more severe in my lower spine.
Have you noticed any redness, soreness, or swelling in the area of severe pain on your lower spine?
No, I haven't noticed any redness, soreness, or swelling in that area.
How would you describe the onset of your back pain – was it sudden or did it build up gradually?
It built up gradually.
Do you have a fever right now, and if so, how high?
Yes, I have a fever, and it's 38.5 degrees Celsius.
Final Diagnosis: Cauda Equina Syndrome secondary to an epidural abscess in the context of HIV infection.
